qas.question: Who used copper to produce art?
What is the photographic technology that uses copper called?
What famous NY city landmark is made from copper?
What famous explorers ships was one of the first to have it's hulls made of copper?
When did The Norddeutsche Affinerie electroplating plant first begin production?
Who used copper to produce garbage?
What is the magical technology that uses copper called?
What famous Arizona city landmark is made from copper?
What unknown explorers ships was one of the first to have it's hulls made of copper?
When did The Norddeutsche Affinerie nuclear plant first begin production?

context: The uses of copper in art were not limited to currency: it was used by <a0_0><b5_0>Renaissance sculptors<b5_0/><a0_0/>, in photographic technology known as the <a1_0><b6_0>daguerreotype<b6_0/><a1_0/>, and the <a2_0><b7_0>Statue of Liberty<b7_0/><a2_0/>. Copper plating and copper sheathing for ships' hulls was widespread; the ships of <a3_0><b8_0>Christopher Columbus<b8_0/><a3_0/> were among the earliest to have this feature. The Norddeutsche Affinerie in Hamburg was the first modern electroplating plant starting its production in 1876. The German scientist Gottfried Osann invented powder metallurgy in <a4_0><b9_0>1830<b9_0/><a4_0/> while determining the metal's atomic mass; around then it was discovered that the amount and type of alloying element (e.g., tin) to copper would affect bell tones. Flash smelting was developed by Outokumpu in Finland and first applied at Harjavalta in 1949; the energy-efficient process accounts for 50% of the world's primary copper production.
